'Walter Leland Cronkite, Jr.' (November 4, 1916 â July 17, 2009) {{cite news |last=Stelter |first=Brian |title=Walter Cronkite,
Iconic Anchorman Dies |publisher=Media Coder |date=July 17, 2009 |url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/17/walter-cronkite-iconic-
anchorman-dies/ |accessdate=2009-07-17 }} {{cite
news |title=CBS Legend Walter Cronkite Dies "Most Trusted Man in America" Passes
Away in New York at 92 |publisher=CBS News |date=July 17, 2009
|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/07/17/eveningnews/main5170556.shtml |accessdate=2009-07-
17 }} {{cite web |last=Ryan |first=Joal |title=News
Legend Walter Cronkite Dead at 92 |publisher=e online |date=July 17, 2009 |url=-
http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b134779_news_legend_walter_cronkite_dead_92.html
|accessdate=2009-07-17 }} was an American broadcast journalist, best known
as anchorman for the [[The CBS Evening News|CBS Evening News]] for 19 years
(1962â1981). During the heyday of [[CBS News]] in the 1960s and 1970s, he was
often cited as "the most trusted man in America" after being so named in an
opinion poll. He reported many events
from 1937 to 1981, including bombings in World War II; the Nuremberg trials;
combat in the Vietnam War; Watergate; the Iran Hostage
Crisis; and the murders of President John F. Kennedy, civil rights pioneer
Martin Luther King, Jr., and Beatles musician John Lennon. He was also known for
his extensive coverage of the U.S. space program, from Project Mercury to the
Moon landings to the Space Shuttle. He was the only non-NASA recipient of a Moon-
rock award. Cronkite is well known for his departing catchphrase "And that's the
way it is," followed by the date on which the appearance aired.
